message.content:
The main difference between plain HTTP and HTTPS protocols is the level of security provided by each protocol. 

HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is an application-level protocol that enables communication between clients and servers, typically used when browsing the internet. It allows for data, such as webpages, images, videos, etc., to be transferred back and forth over a network in a structured manner.

However, HTTP does not include any built-in mechanisms for encrypting or securing the data being transmitted. This means any information sent or received using plain HTTP may be subject to potential eavesdropping or man-in-the-middle attacks from malicious third parties.

HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure), on the other hand, provides additional security measures to protect sensitive data during transmission over networks. With HTTPS in place, all communications between clients and servers are encrypted using SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) encryption technology before being sent out onto the network.

This encryption ensures that even if one's data were intercepted during transit (e.g., by hackers), it would appear as unintelligible gibberish since it cannot be easily decrypted without access to private encryption keys managed by both parties involved in fetching or transmitting content via this secure method.

Overall then—compared with regular HTTP-based connections—implementations through HTTPS proactively safeguard user privacy while lending assurance about legitimate identities being affiliated with some specific website platform engaged through browsing experiences online.
